history.p: The song was presumably composed at the end of 1923. A number of sketches can be dated to December. The song survives in no fewer than eight complete versions in Nielsen's hand, all from 1924; of these, five were printed while three are known only in manuscript.

bibl.author: Audivi [Hugo Seligmann]
Carl Nielsen
bibl.title: Carl Nielsen og hans Sangbog for Folket
Politiken

bibl.author: Inter.
Carl Nielsen
bibl.title: En ny Sangbog af Carl Nielsen
Berlingske Tidende

bibl.author: Erik Abrahamsen
bibl.title: Tonekunsten: En Vejledning til dens Forstaaelse

history.p: This version survives in manuscript only. It was sent to music dealer L. Siboni on 20 June 1924, who apparently had encouraged Nielsen to re-arrange the melody.
According to the printer's manuscript this version was planned to be published on 2 June 1924.
According to the Wilhelm Hansen's engravers' book, this version for five-voice choir was produced in February 1924.
After the first performance of the song, this version was published in August 1924.
This version was apparently made on a request of the local magistrate in Skibby. Nielsen sent the score to him with a letter dated 28 January 1924.
The only surviving source for this version is an undated draft.

expression.title: Version for five-part mixed choir and orchestra (partly lost)

history.p: The only surviving source for this version is an undated sketch. However, a performance is documented in the programme for a gala concert at The Royal Theatre on 1 June 1924. A letter from Nielsen to Asger Wilhelm Hansen also refers to what must be assumed to be this version.

relation.label: Arrangement not by Nielsen: See Appendix

titleStmt.title: Score, autograph, fair copy without text

annot.p: Ink fair copy with text added in a foreign hand.
